College of Energy Soochow Institute for Energy and Materials InnovationS (SIEMIS) Soochow University Suzhou 215006 Jiangsu China Graphical abstract High-throughput computational method is used to screen novel materials from the large number of oxide double perovskites for optoelectronics and photocatalysis applications. Oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6 are a class of emerging materials in the fields of optoelectronics and catalysis. Due to the chemical flexibilities of perovskite structures, there are multiple elemental combinations of cations A, B′, and B′′, which leading to tremendous candidates. In this study, we comprehensively screened stable oxide double perovskite A2B′B′′O6 from a pool of 2,018 perovskite candidates using a high-throughput computational approach. By considering a tolerance factor (t)–octahedral factor (μ) phase diagram, 138 candidates with F m 3 ¯ m , P21/c, and R3c phases were selected and systematically studied via first-principles calculations based on density functional theory. The screening procedure finally predicted the existence of 21 stable perovskites, and 14 among them have never been reported. Verification with existing experimental results demonstrates that the prediction accuracy for perovskite formability is approximately 90%. The predicted oxide double perovskites exhibit quasi-direct bandgaps ranging from 0 to 4.4 eV with a significantly small direct-indirect bandgap difference, balanced electron and hole effective masses, and strong optical absorptions. The newly predicted oxide double perovskites may enlarge the pool of material candidates for applications in optoelectronics and photocatalysis. This study provides a route for computational screening of novel perovskites for functional applications. Keywords Oxide double perovskites First-principles calculations High-throughput Optoelectronics Photocatalysis 1 Introduction Oxide perovskites, a class of traditional materials, have played a crucial role in materials research over the past several decades owing to their structural flexibility, compositional versatility, and chemical stability [1–7]. Research history shows that the discovery of a new perovskite may lead to a new field. For example, perovskite BaTiO3, discovered in the 1940 s [8], demonstrated for the first time that ferroelectricity could exist in simple oxide. BaTiO3 is still the most widely used ferroelectric material because of its rich coupling and tunable interaction associated with ferroelectric phenomena [9–11]. In the 1980 s, Cu-based perovskites Ba-La-Cu-O (Ba x La5- x Cu5O5(3- y ) [x = 1 and 0.75, y > 0]) accelerated the development of high-temperature superconductors and became a prototypical system for the study of high-temperature superconductors [12–14]. Perovskite-type manganese-based oxides [15], such as La0.67Ca0.33MnO x , La1- x Sr x MnO3, Pr1- x Sr x MnO3 and Pr1- x Ca x MnO3, have been the most prominent materials that have exhibited colossal magnetoresistance from the 1990 s owing to their polaronic effects resulting from strong electron-phonon coupling and ferromagnetic interactions, and double-exchange interaction resulting from Mn3+/Mn4+ mixed valency [16,17]. Oxide perovskites also play important roles in the applications of energy harvesting and utilization, such as photocatalysis, photoelectrocatalysis, and photovoltaic applications. Prototype oxide perovskites SrTiO3, KNbO3, AgNbO3, and LaFeO3 have been an important family of catalysts for oxygen evolution reaction applications in the past 60 years [7,18–21]. The discovery of novel oxide perovskites is becoming a promising field owing to the versatile applications of oxide perovskites. One of the approaches is a chemical mutation of oxide-single perovskite (ABO3) to oxide double perovskites (A2B′B′′O6), i.e., B → B′ + B′′. In this case, the pool of material candidates is significantly expanded, and novel applications can be expected. Nechache et al. fabricated the multilayer heterostructure Bi2FeCrO6-based solar cells, which achieved a power conversion efficiency (PCE) up to 8.1% [22]. Sun et al. explored stable oxide double perovskites A2M(III)M(V)O6 (A = Ca, Sr, Ba; M(III) = Sb3+, Bi3+; M(V) = V5+, Nb5+, Ta5+), which exhibit direct bandgaps ranging from 0.3 to 3.8 eV [23]. Among them, Ba2BiNbO6 was synthesized and exhibited promising photocatalysis application for H2 generation [7,24–26]. Volonakis et al. synthesized a new oxide double perovskite Ba2AgIO6 with a direct bandgap of 1.93 eV, which was proposed as an excellent candidate for optoelectronics and energy applications [27]. The iodine ion in Ba2AgIO6 has a + 7 oxidation state, which is very rare. Intuitively, the existence of Ba2AgIO6 may does not seem feasible, but it has been successfully synthesized, which indicates that there may be a large number of oxide double perovskites that remain unexplored. Theoretical exploration of unknown materials not only greatly improves the efficiency of trial and error in experiments, but often provides unexpected results. Currently, density functional theory computations, high-throughput computations, and machine learning are the mainstream methods for material design and selection. Zhou et al. found using density functional theory computations that Ca5V4O15 nanosheet was a promising photocatalyst for visible-light water splitting from a series of A5B4O15 (A = Ca, Sr, Ba; B = V, Nb, Ta) layered perovskite materials [28]. MgSrMnO4 and Mg2SrMn2O7 have considerable potential in the field of luminous energy conversion from a series of Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites [29]. Kuhar et al. identified 74 materials with potential use as light absorbers in photovoltaic or photoelectrochemical devices from more than 20,000 materials using high-throughput computational approaches [30]. Moreover, this method can be used in other fields, such as semiconductor light-emitting diodes and transparent conducting materials [31]. In addition, novel materials design via machine learning has drawn much interest in many fields, such as photovoltaic materials [32], lithium-ion battery materials [33,34], and glass material system [35,36]. Moreover, this approach is being optimized and updated continually [37,38]. In this study, we carried out a comprehensive study on A2B′B′′O6 oxide double perovskite using high-throughput computational approaches, as shown in Fig. 1 , to discover novel oxide perovskites for energy-harvesting applications. 2018 possible candidates of oxide double perovskites, (192, 363, 231, 168, 616, and 448 for A2 1+B4+B6+O6, A2 2+B2+B6+O6, A2 2+B3+B5+O6, A2 3+B1+B5+O6, A2 3+B2+B4+O6 and A2 4+B1+B3+O6), respectively, are shown in Fig. 2 . The stability screening was initially performed by using t-u phase diagram and then by first-principles calculations. This identified 14 novel and stable oxide double perovskites. They exhibited superior electronic properties and strong optical absorptions, which was proposed to be suitable for optoelectronic and photocatalysis applications. 2 Experimental The first-principles calculations were performed using DFT [39,40], as implemented in the VASP code [41,42] by the standard frozen-core projector augmented-wave (PAW) method [43]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [44] functional of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used for the exchange-correlation function. In geometry optimization, all atoms were fully relaxed until the residual Hellman-Feynman force became smaller than 0.01 eV/Å, and the energy convergence with the energy difference was below 10-5 eV between two consecutive self-consistent field iteration steps. In the calculations, a 500 eV plane-wave cutoff energy was employed and the Brillouin Zone was sampled using a 6 × 6 × 6, 6 × 6 × 6 and 6 × 2 × 4 k-grid mesh for the F m 3 ¯ m , R3c, and P21/c phase, respectively. To better evaluate the bandgaps of the 21 types of oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6, a hybrid Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE) [45] funcrional was used with a standard 25% Hartree-Fock exchange (a = 0.25, i.e., PBE0). The frequency-dependent dielectric function ε ω = ε 1 ω + i ε 2 ( ω ) was calculated using PAW. Subsequently, the absorption coefficient as a function of photon energy was calculated using the expression a E = 4 π e hc { [ ε 1 2 + ε 2 2 ] 1 / 2 - ε 1 2 } [46]. The optical spectrum calculation based on PBE0 has a high computational cost; hence, all optical absorption spectra were calculated based on the PBE function. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material candidates Ascribed to chemical flexibility, the combination of various cations such as A, B′, and B′′ in a periodic table (Fig. 2) provides thousands of candidates for oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6. To maintain the charge balance, A2B′B′′O6 must satisfy the following equation: (1) 2 Q A + Q B ′ + Q B ′′ = 12 In this study, we did not consider B′ and B′′ to have the same charged states. Based on the charge balance and Table 1 , there are six classes of oxide double perovskite, namely, A2 1+B4+B6+O6 (class-1), A2 2+B2+B6+O6 (class-2), A2 2+B3+B5+O6 (class-3), A2 3+B1+B5+O6 (class-4), A2 3+B2+B4+O6 (class-5), and A2 4+B1+B3+O6 (class-6). The number of perovskites in each class is listed in Fig. 2 and Table 2 . There are additional candidates of oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6; the B′ and B′′ cations that have transition metal elements with d orbital partially occupied. In this case, the results of first-principles calculations depend considerably on the spin configurations, magnetic orders, and empirical on-site Coulomb U added on d orbital, resulting in computational uncertainties and discrepancies. Therefore, in this study, we did not include such types of perovskites and only considered cation B′ and B′′ with orbital configurations of d 0 (fully unoccupied) and d 10 (fully occupied). 3.2 Material screening via stability descriptor First-principles calculations based on density-functional theory for a total of 2,018 perovskite candidates have high computational costs. Perovskite formability can be empirically estimated by chemical descriptors owing to the chemical flexibility and high-symmetry structure, facilitating the fast screening of stable/unstable perovskites. For example, tolerance factor (t), defined as R A + R O 2 ( R B + R O ) [47], and octahedral factor (μ), defined as R B/R O, where R A, R B, and R O are ionic radius of ions A, B and O respectively, are long-lasting stability descriptors for perovskites that play a crucial role in discovering and engineering stable perovskites. For oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6, μ is calculated as R B ′ + R B ′ ′ 2 R O and t is calculated as R A + R O 2 ( R B ′ + R B ′ ′ 2 + R O ) , where R A, R B′, R B′′, and R O are ionic radii A, B′, B′′, and O, respectively. Statistics on existing oxide perovskites by Li et al. [3,48] show that the perovskite structure can be formed in the range 0.71 < t < 1.0 and 0.42 < μ < 0.75. Recently, Sun et al. determined a critical line of t + μ = constant for stable/unstable perovskites in t-μ phase diagram [49]. The t-μ phase diagram in Fig. 3 (a) shows 2,018 perovskite candidates. There are 234 perovskite candidates that meet the stability criteria of Li et al. [3,48] and Sun et al. [49], as shown by the dashed line in Fig. 3(a). The total number of stable materials after screening is represented by the individual classes in Fig. 3(b). The stable perovskites are mainly in classes 1 – 3, while the majority of perovskites in classes 4–6 are unstable. This can be explained by the greater ionic A size of + 1 (class 1) and + 2 (classes 2 and 3) charged cations compared with that of + 3 (classes 4 and 5) and + 4 (class 6) charged cations. Most class-3 perovskites have been explored recently [23]; hence, the remainder of this study will focus on the class-1 and class-2 perovskites. 3.3 Material screening via first-principles calculations Descriptors are empirical criteria for perovskite formability. The quantitative estimation of thermodynamic stability requires first-principles calculations on decomposition energy (ΔH D), which is defined as (2) Δ H D A 2 B ′ B ′′ O 6 = ∑ E product - E ( A 2 B ′ B ′′ O 6 ) where E product and E(A2B′B′′O6) are the total energies of decomposed products and perovske A2B′B′′O6, respectively. Although the cubic phase ( F m 3 ¯ m ) is the model system of perovskites, real perovskites tend to distort to lower symmetry and consequently release the strain energy because of the B-site ionic size mismatch. An extensive survey of perovskite phases in ICSD demonstrated that three phases ( F m 3 ¯ m , R3c and P21/c) are dominant in oxide perovskites. Therefore, these three phases, as shown in Fig. 4 , are chosen as crystal structures of perovskite candidates for further studies. As shown in Eq. (2), at a particular phase of A2B′B′′O6, the amount of ΔH D is greatly dependent on the ∑E product, i.e., the decomposition pathways. The most common approach is to consider binary oxides [23,50]. However, for oxide double perovskites, consideration of ternary oxides and redox reaction is crucial when determining the stability of perovskites that contain ions with multiple valance charges, [51,52] such as Ge, Sn, and Pb with Ge2+, Sn2+, and Pb2+ and Ge4+, Sn4+, and Pb4+ ions, respectively. We considered five and ten pathways for class-1 and class-2 perovskites, respectively, considering the previous studies (Tables S1 and S3). The calculated decomposition energies of class-1 perovskites for five different pathways are shown in Table S2. The decomposition energies of the optimal pathways are shown in Fig. S1, with a mixture of binary and ternary oxides. This heat map of decomposition energies revealed that P21/c phase of the material is more stable than the F m 3 ¯ m and R3c phase. However, the decomposition energies of all class-1 perovskites are less than zero. We did not find any class-1 perovskites successfully synthesized in ICSD or literature. The calculated decomposition energies of class-2 perovskites for ten different pathways are shown in Tables S3 and S4. Here, the considerations for the ten different decomposition paths include all possible combinations of different decomposition products (Table S3). A comparison of the decomposition energies of each material in different paths (Table S4) revealed that the following two pathways are optimal for most class-2 perovskites: (3) A2B′(II)B′′ (VI)O6 → AO + B′(II)O2 + AB′′(VI)O4 and (4) A2B′(II)B′′ (VI)O6 → 2AO + B′(II)B′′(VI)O4 i.e., the products are mainly mixed binary and ternary oxides. The decomposition energy of 360 materials for the optimal decomposition path (minimum decomposition energy) is shown in Fig. 5 ; the materials tend to be stable when the color tends to red. This heat map demonstrates that the stability of perovskites follows the sequence of A-site as Ba > Sr > Ca > Mg. At specific A-site cation, oxide double perovskite tends to be more stable when the ionic radius of B′(II) is close to that of B′′(VI), minimizing the strain energy from lattice mismatch. Furthermore, the selection of materials is based on decomposition energy, the selection criteria ΔH D > 0 is determined not only for theoretical possibilities, but in combination with material data already found experimentally, as displayed in the following section. 3.4 Verification by experimental data To verify our theoretical prediction, we extensively examined oxide double perovskites of classes 1 and 2 in ICSD and literature. The results demonstrate that only a small amount of perovskites has been synthesized with the F m 3 ¯ m and P21/c phases in the experiment (Table 3 ), while the R3c phases have not been found, although the F m 3 ¯ m and R3c phases are more stable than P21/c phase, as shown in the heat map (Fig. 5). Such discrepancies may be ascribed to different amounts of entropy contributions at finite temperatures for different phases. Therefore, we mainly considered the F m 3 ¯ m and P21/c phases, compared them with the experimental results, and identified stable perovskites. The calculated decomposition energies and its comparison with experimental results for F m 3 ¯ m phase are shown in Fig. 6 , and that of the P21/c phase are shown in Fig. S2. The prediction accuracy is approximately 90% when ΔH D = 0 is chosen as a critical line for stable/unstable phases. Based on the screening via stability descriptor, DFT calculations, and experimental verifications, we identified 21 oxide double perovskites, 14 of which have F m 3 ¯ m phases and seven of which have P21/c phases, as shown in Table 3. The stable F m 3 ¯ m phases are more than stable P21/c phases, which is consistent with the calculation results that F m 3 ¯ m phase is more stable than P21/c phase shown in the heat map (Fig. 5). Seven of them were synthesized in previous experiments and used for optoelectronic and photocatalysis applications. For example, Ba2MgWO6 [53,54] and Ba2ZnWO6 [53] exhibit luminescence with green and yellow emissions in room-temperature; Ba2CaMoO6 [55] and Ba2CaWO6 [56] phosphors may be used as orange-red phosphors for white light-emitting diodes, and Ba2CaWO6 [57] is employed in the PEC water splitting. Fourteen of them have never been reported; therefore, it is important to examine the electronic and optical properties of those fourteen oxide perovskites in comparison to the seven existing oxide perovskites, to investigate their potential in optoelectronic and photocatalysis applications. 3.5 Electronic and optical properties First-principles calculations were performed to investigate the electronic and optical properties for the above 21 oxide perovskites. PBE-calculated band structures for 21 oxide perovskites are displayed in Fig. S3. Among them, Ba2SrWO6, Ba2HgWO6 ( F m 3 ¯ m ), and Ba2SrWO6 (P21/c) are chosen as examples; their band structures and partial density of states (pDOS) are displayed in Fig. 7 . Ba2SrWO6 exhibits quasi-direct bandgaps, with the conduction band minimum (CBM) and valence band maximum (VBM) located on the X point and the X-G high symmetry point, respectively. The difference of indirect and direct bandgap (ΔE g = E g dir−E g indir) is as small as 0.06 eV, as displayed in Fig. 7(a). The pDOS demonstrates that the CBM and VBM are mainly contributed by W d orbital and O p orbital, respectively. Ba2HgWO6 exhibits an indirect bandgap, with CBM and VBM located on the X and L point, respectively. The CBM is mainly contributed by W d and Hg s orbitals, and the VBM is mainly contributed by O p orbital and Hg d orbitals, as displayed in Fig. 7(b). Ba2SrWO6 (P21/c) exhibits a small ΔE g of 0.08 eV. The CBM is mainly contributed by W d orbitals, which is located on the L point, and VBM located on L and G points, as displayed in Fig. 7(c). The A-site cations of all perovskites do not contribute to the VBM or CBM. These materials exhibit a balanced electron and hole effective mass, as displayed in Table S5. The PBE and PBE0 calculated bandgaps are shown in Fig. 7(d). They exhibit a wide bandgap in the range of approximately 1.9–4.5 eV, except for Sr2GeCrO6 (0 eV). The diffuse reflectance UV–visible absorbance spectra for Ba2MgWO6 and Ba2ZnWO6 display their absorption edges at 365 and 355 nm, corresponding to the bandgap of 3.4 eV and 3.5 eV [53], slightly below the PBE calculated results of 4.02 eV and 4.19 eV, respectively. Most oxide double perovskites exhibit quasi-direct bandgaps, i.e., small indirect and direct bandgap differences ranging from approximately 0.01 to 0.14 eV, as illustrated in Table S5. This amount is comparable to that of CH3NH3PbI3 (0.025 eV) [61,62], and is much smaller than that of halide double perovskites Cs2AgBiX6 (X = Cl, Br, I) (0.45–0.71 eV) [63–65]. Small ΔE g (less than 0.10 eV) does not have a significant impact on the optical properties and could facilitate electron-hole separation to avoid fast recombination, leading to longer carrier lifetime. For example, the recombination rate of photogenerated electrons and holes slowed down in hybrid organic–inorganic perovskite CH3NH3PbI3 because of the phonon-assisted process in indirect bandgap [66,67]. In addition to the electronic properties of the materials, optical absorption is a crucial property for optoelectronic and photocatalysis applications. For clarity, we demonstrate the calculated optical absorption of Ba2SrMoO6, Ba2SrWO6, Ba2CdMoO6, Ba2CdWO6 ( F m 3 ¯ m ), and Ba2SrWO6 (P21/c) in Fig. 8 , in comparison with CH3NH3PbI3. (The results of all other perovskites are shown in Fig. S4). There are very sharp absorption edges and strong absorption strengths, in comparison with CH3NH3PbI3. In CH3NH3PbI3, the optical absorption is obtained mainly from the p-p transitions and intra-atomic Pb s-p transitions. For oxide double perovskite, the optical absorption is obtained mainly from the O p to B′′(VI) d transition. 4 Conclusions We comprehensively screened stable candidates in a pool of 2,018 oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6, via to the stability descriptor, phase diagram, and first-principles calculations. Verification with experiments demonstrated a prediction accuracy of approximately 90%. Twenty-one oxide double perovskites have been identified and fourteen of them have never been reported. The standard method of solid state chemical reaction was adopted for materials synthesis [60]. Further first-principles calculations demonstrated that those perovskites have quasi-direct bandgaps, balanced electron and hole effective masses, and strong optical absorption; therefore, they may be suitable for optoelectronic and photocatalysis applications. coredata.dc:description: Oxide double perovskites A2B′B′′O6 are a class of emerging materials in the fields of optoelectronics and catalysis. Due to the chemical flexibilities of perovskite structures, there are multiple elemental combinations of cations A, B′, and B′′, which leading to tremendous candidates. In this study, we comprehensively screened stable oxide double perovskite A2B′B′′O6 from a pool of 2,018 perovskite candidates using a high-throughput computational approach. By considering a tolerance factor (t)–octahedral factor (μ) phase diagram, 138 candidates with F m 3 ¯ m , P21/c, and R3c phases were selected and systematically studied via first-principles calculations based on density functional theory. The screening procedure finally predicted the existence of 21 stable perovskites, and 14 among them have never been reported. Verification with existing experimental results demonstrates that the prediction accuracy for perovskite formability is approximately 90%. The predicted oxide double perovskites exhibit quasi-direct bandgaps ranging from 0 to 4.4 eV with a significantly small direct-indirect bandgap difference, balanced electron and hole effective masses, and strong optical absorptions. The newly predicted oxide double perovskites may enlarge the pool of material candidates for applications in optoelectronics and photocatalysis. This study provides a route for computational screening of novel perovskites for functional applications.
